Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Teaching Bias Mitigation through Training Games with Application in Credibility Attribution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that will help envision the next generation of learning technologies and advance what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. Cyberlearning Exploration (EXP) Projects explore the viability of new kinds of learning technologies by designing and building new kinds of learning technologies and studying their possibilities for fostering learning and challenges to using them effectively. This project will develop and study an interactive game entitled VERITAS for making players aware of their cognitive bias in decision making and attempting to mitigate its effects. The game focuses on detecting deception and many of the research participants are from law enforcement.

Heuristics are cognitive shortcuts acquired from existing beliefs and past experiences. Heuristics and cognitive biases affect virtually every judgment being made in daily life. Humans often perform no better than chance when attempting to distinguish truths from deception and tend to be over-confident in their ability to detect deception. They are rarely aware of their own biases and are resistant to traditional training efforts aimed at changing decision-making processes. There are few studies verifying our ability to mitigate cognitive biases. This project will explore using game-based learning to make people aware of cognitive biases and reduce their reliance on simple heuristics. The project asserts that the experiential environment afforded by game-based learning should be particularly effective at facilitating the introspection necessary for learners to actively experiment with more systematic decision-making techniques. It will experimentally test the effectiveness of a game-based training program targeting law enforcement officials. This research integrates a theory-driven design using multiple research methods, including observation of behavior during game play, surveys, interviewing, and experimentation. This project will contribute to the understanding of how cognitive biases function within the context of deception detection and will advance understanding of how a game may be better suited than traditional learning methods at mitigating cognitive biases. Results will be disseminated through convention exhibitions and journal publications and the team plans to showcase this game at professional conferences with game developers, law enforcement officials, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research shows the average human is only able to identify the difference between truths and lies at a 54% accuracy rate (Bond & DePaulo, 2006).  These odds are only slightly better than flipping a coin.  Though most people are likely to be duped by low stakes lies with minimal consequences, others may be misled by high stakes lies that significantly impact their wellbeing, safety, and livelihood.  In this regard, law enforcement officers (LEOs) are routinely required to make high stakes credibility assessments on a daily basis.  Though conventional training can help officers distinguish between deceptive and truthful behaviors, studies show officers are no better at detecting deception than the average untrained citizen (Granhag & Vrij, 2010; Vrij & Mann, 2001). People who do not have a valid basis for forming their credibility assessments often depend on biases and cognitive short-cuts that are unsound and unreliable.  Hence, law enforcement officers would greatly benefit from new approaches to training that better prepare them to more reliably distinguish between instances of veracity and deception.

Led by principal investigator, Norah Dunbar, our research team has developed a new digital learning game called VERITAS (Veracity Education and Reactance Instruction through Technology and Applied Skills).  The goal of VERITAS is to teach deception detection skills to LEOs and laypersons alike.  Mandatory play-time within VERITAS lasts approximately one hour, during which players work through two scenarios assessing whether the subjects are lying or telling the truth.  In Scenario 1, players interview a job applicant to assess her trustworthiness; in Scenario 2, players interrogate a suspect to evaluate whether she has knowledge of a workplace theft. The game presents clues to deception in three cue clusters involving uncertainty, tension, and high cognitive load on the part of deceivers.

An evaluation program was conducted to determine the effectiveness of VERITAS at training samples of LEOs and lay people about the reliability of various deception detection cues. Four studies were conducted: (1) a series of focus groups with 59 VERITAS players at two Universities provided preliminary feedback about the game, (2) an experiment with 510 student players at three Universities assessed the game’s training effectiveness, (3) a study with 36 LEOs from four different agencies assessed how the game performed with an LEO sample in comparison to the student sample, and (4) an experiment with 191 students from three different universities to test the effectiveness of a shorter, revised version of VERITAS relative to the longer version.  Results show VERITAS to be more effective than a traditional PowerPoint lecture at motivating and engaging learners, at teaching players to recognize truthful vs. deceptive statements, and especially at improving knowledge about clusters of reliable deception cues.  LEOs were more motivated than students to improve their performance, and whereas students improved 10-11% in their deception detection accuracy from scenario 1 to scenario 2 in the game, LEOs improved by 16%.  Overall, the game was effective at both motivating learners to engage with the training materials as well as teaching them to better identify reliable cues to deception.

This project contributes directly to our understanding of how people can learn to overcome their biases, and how specialized skills such as deception detection can be improved via game-based learning. Moreover, this project advances our understanding of the conditions under which people react less defensively and more favorably towards training designed to change their deep beliefs and heuristics. VERITAS explored new ways of using game mechanics to overcome problematic heuristics that often lead to poor decision-making due to cognitive biases. The research findings from this project have the potential to transform educational and training programs across a range of professions in which biases interfere with sound decision-making processes, especially within legal, corporate, and medical environments.

Effective law enforcement interrogation and credibility assessment present important challenges extending beyond the scope of standard training methodologies.  Research into the efficacy of serious video games has the potential to impact society in significant ways by developing training programs designed to teach LEOs skills fundamental to their daily work. Such methods give them a set of research-based tools useful in limiting their reliance on cognitive biases, allowing them to perform their duties more effectively, as well as interact more successfully with the public.  

Bond, C. F., Jr., & DePaulo, B. M. (2006). Accuracy of deception judgments. Personality and Social Psychology Review, 10(3), 214-234.

Granhag, P. A., & Vrij, A. (2010). Interviewing to detect deception. In P. A. Granhag (Ed.), Forensic psychology in context: Nordic and international approaches. (pp. 75-93). Devon, UK: Willan Publishing.

Vrij, A., & Mann, S. (2001). Who killed my relative? Police officers' ability to detect real-life high-stake lies. Psychology, crime and law, 7(1-4), 119-132.
